title: Contributor Code of Conduct
text: contributors maintainers project, pledge respect people contribute reporting issues, posting feature requests, updating documentation, submitting pull requests patches, activities. committed making participation project harassment-free experience everyone, regardless level experience, gender, gender identity expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, age, religion. Examples unacceptable behavior participants include use sexual language imagery, derogatory comments personal attacks, trolling, public private harassment, insults, unprofessional conduct. Project maintainers right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct. Project maintainers follow Code Conduct may removed project team. Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported opening issue contacting one project maintainers. Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant (http:contributor-covenant.org), version 1.0.0, available http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/0/0/

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: can install aRxiv package via CRAN: use remotes::install_github() get (possibly recent) version GitHub:
code: install.packages("aRxiv") install.packages("remotes") library(remotes) install_github("ropensci/aRxiv")

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: Use arxiv_search() search arXiv, arxiv_count() get simple count manuscripts matching query, arxiv_open() open abstract pages set results arxiv_search(). ’ll get details moment. now, let’s look examples. Suppose wanted identify arXiv manuscripts “Peter Hall” author. best first get count, sense many records search return. (Peter Hall “among world’s prolific highly cited authors probability statistics.”) first use library() load aRxiv package arxiv_count() get count. au: part indicates search author field; use double quotes search phrase. obtain actual records matching query, use arxiv_search(). default grab 10 records; limit can changed limit argument. note arXiv API let download 50,000 records, even case ’s best batches; . Also note result arxiv_search() attribute "total_results" containing total count search results; arxiv_count() provides. following get us 67 records. arxiv_search() returns data frame row single manuscript. columns different fields (e.g., authors, title, abstract, etc.). Fields like authors contain multiple items single character string multiple items separated vertical bar (|). might interested restrictive search, Peter Hall’s arXiv manuscripts deconvolution title. use ti: search title field, combine two . Let’s display just authors title results. can open abstract pages 4 manuscripts using arxiv_open(). takes, input, output arxiv_search().
code: library(aRxiv) arxiv_count('au:"Peter Hall"') ## [1] 67 rec <- arxiv_search('au:"Peter Hall"') nrow(rec) ## [1] 10 attr(rec, "total_results") ## [1] 67 rec <- arxiv_search('au:"Peter Hall"', limit=100) nrow(rec) ## [1] 67 deconv <- arxiv_search('au:"Peter Hall" AND ti:deconvolution') nrow(deconv) ## [1] 4 deconv[, c('title', 'authors')] ##                                                                             title ## 1                                     A ridge-parameter approach to deconvolution ## 2                                     On deconvolution with repeated measurements ## 3 Estimation of distributions, moments and quantiles in deconvolution\n  problems ## 4   Kernel methods and minimum contrast estimators for empirical\n  deconvolution ##                                        authors ## 1                 Peter Hall|Alexander Meister ## 2 Aurore Delaigle|Peter Hall|Alexander Meister ## 3               Peter Hall|Soumendra N. Lahiri ## 4                   Aurore Delaigle|Peter Hall arxiv_open(deconv)

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: two basic arguments arxiv_count() arxiv_search() query, character string representing search, id_list, list arXiv manuscript identifiers. query provided, manuscripts matching query returned. id_list provided, manuscripts list returned. provided, manuscripts id_list match query returned. query may single character string vector character strings. vector, elements pasted together . id_list may vector character strings single comma-separated character string.

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: Generally, one ignore id_list focus forming query argument. aRxiv package includes dataset query_terms lists terms (like au) can use. Use colon (:) separate query term actual query. Multiple queries can combined , , ANDNOT. default . appears author field (many fields) must search full words, wild cards allowed.
code: query_terms ##               term                                      description ## 1               ti                                            Title ## 2               au                                           Author ## 3              abs                                         Abstract ## 4               co                                          Comment ## 5               jr                                Journal Reference ## 6              cat                                 Subject Category ## 7               rn                                    Report Number ## 8              all                                 All of the above ## 9    submittedDate Date/time of initial submission, as YYYYMMDDHHMM ## 10 lastUpdatedDate        Date/time of last update, as YYYYMMDDHHMM arxiv_count('au:Peter au:Hall') ## [1] 38112 arxiv_count('au:Peter OR au:Hall') ## [1] 38112 arxiv_count('au:Peter AND au:Hall') ## [1] 161 arxiv_count('au:Hall ANDNOT au:Peter') ## [1] 2764 arxiv_count('au:P* AND au:Hall') ## [1] 0 arxiv_count('au:P AND au:Hall') ## [1] 1236 arxiv_count('au:"P Hall"') ## [1] 44

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: arXiv set 155 subject classifications, searchable prefix cat:. aRxiv package contains dataset arxiv_cats containing categories, short long descriptions, well field (, Physics, subfield). column names. statistics categories. search categories, need include either full term use * wildcard.
code: colnames(arxiv_cats) ## [1] "category"          "field"             "subfield"          ## [4] "short_description" "long_description" arxiv_cats[arxiv_cats$field=="Statistics", c("category", "short_description")] ##     category short_description ## 150  stat.AP      Applications ## 151  stat.CO       Computation ## 152  stat.ME       Methodology ## 153  stat.ML  Machine Learning ## 154  stat.OT  Other Statistics ## 155  stat.TH Statistics Theory arxiv_count('cat:stat') ## [1] 0 arxiv_count('cat:stat.AP') ## [1] 17806 arxiv_count('cat:stat*') ## [1] 116194

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: terms submittedDate (date/time first submission) lastUpdatedDate (date/time last revision) particularly useful limiting search many results, may combine multiple searches together, within window time, get full results. date/time information form YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, example 20071018122534 2007-10-18 12:25:34. can use * wildcard times. example, get manuscripts initial submission 2007-10-18: can’t use wildcard within dates. get count manuscripts original submission 2007, use date range, like [from_date to_date]. (give partial date, ’s treated earliest date/time matches, range appears including second date/time.)
code: arxiv_count('submittedDate:20071018*') ## [1] 196 arxiv_count('submittedDate:2007*') ## [1] 0 arxiv_count('submittedDate:[2007 TO 2008]') ## [1] 55749

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: output arxiv_search() data frame following columns. columns described help file arxiv_search(). Try ?arxiv_search. short notes: field single character string. authors, link_doi, categories may contain multiple items, separated vertical bar (|). Missing entries empty character string (""). categories column may contain just aRxiv categories (e.g., stat.AP) also codes Mathematical Subject Classification (MSC) (e.g., 14J60) ACM Computing Classification System (e.g., F.2.2). searchable cat: searchable general search.
code: res <- arxiv_search('au:"Peter Hall"') names(res) ##  [1] "id"               "submitted"        "updated"          "title"            ##  [5] "abstract"         "authors"          "affiliations"     "link_abstract"    ##  [9] "link_pdf"         "link_doi"         "comment"          "journal_ref"      ## [13] "doi"              "primary_category" "categories" arxiv_count("cat:14J60") ## [1] 0 arxiv_count("14J60") ## [1] 880

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: arxiv_search() function two arguments sorting results, sort_by (taking values "submitted", "updated", "relevance") ascending (TRUE FALSE). id_list provided, sorting arguments ignored results presented according order id_list. ’s example, sort results date manuscripts last updated, descending order.
code: res <- arxiv_search('au:"Peter Hall" AND ti:deconvolution',                     sort_by="updated", ascending=FALSE) res$updated ## [1] "2010-03-01 11:33:37" "2008-10-27 14:27:52" "2008-04-04 12:19:05" ## [4] "2007-10-18 12:25:34"

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: arXiv metadata number limitations, key issue author-supplied necessarily consistent records. Authors’ names may vary records (e.g., Peter Hall vs. Peter G. Hall vs. Peter Gavin Hall vs. P Hall). , arXiv provides ability distinguish multiple individuals name (c.f., ORCID). Authors’ institutional affiliations mostly missing. arXiv submission form include affiliation field; affiliations entered within author field, parentheses. metadata instructions may widely read. key words; stuck searching free text titles abstracts. Subject classifications provided authors may incomplete inappropriate.

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: Care taken avoid multiple requests arXiv API short period time. arXiv API user manual states: cases API needs called multiple times row, encourage play nice incorporate 3 second delay code. aRxiv package institutes delay requests, time period delay configurable R option "aRxiv_delay" (seconds). default 3 seconds. reduce delay 1 second, use: Don’t searches parallel (e.g., via parallel package). may locked arXiv API.
code: options(aRxiv_delay=1)

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: arXiv API returns complete records (including entire abstracts); searches returning large numbers records can slow. ’s best use arxiv_count() arxiv_search(), sense many records receive. count large, may wish refine query. arXiv hard limit around 50,000 records; query matches 50,000 manuscripts, way receive full results. simplest solution problem break query smaller pieces, example using slices time, range dates submittedDate lastUpdatedDate. limit argument arxiv_search() (default limit=10) limits number records returned. wish receive 10 records, must specify larger limit (e.g., limit=100). avoid accidental searches may return large number records, arxiv_search() uses R option, aRxiv_toomany (default 15,000), refuses attempt search return results limit.

title: aRxiv tutorial
text: Even searches return moderate number records (say 2,000), may best make requests batches: Use smaller value limit argument (say 100), make multiple requests different offsets, indicated start argument, initial record return. done automatically batchsize argument arxiv_search(). search split multiple calls, batchsize records returned , results combined.

title: Interface to the arXiv API
text: Installation instructions Stable Version can install package via CRAN: Development Version use remotes::install_github() get (recent) version GitHub:
code: install.packages("aRxiv") install.packages("remotes") library(remotes) install_github("ropensci/aRxiv")

title: Interface to the arXiv API
text: main function arxiv_search(). ’s example use:
code: library(aRxiv) z <- arxiv_search(query = 'au:"Peter Hall" AND cat:stat*', limit=50) str(z)

Papers on computer communication systems and network protocols (e.g. TCP/IP) are generally a closer fit to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) category. #> 40                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               cs.SY is an alias for eess.SY. This section includes theoretical and experimental research covering all facets of automatic control systems. The section is focused on methods of control system analysis and design using tools of modeling, simulation and optimization. Specific areas of research include nonlinear, distributed, adaptive, stochastic and robust control in addition to hybrid and discrete event systems. Application areas include automotive and aerospace control systems, network control, biological systems, multiagent and cooperative control, robotics, reinforcement learning, sensor networks, control of cyber-physical and energy-related systems, and control of computing systems. #> 41 signals representing audio, speech, and language, and their applications. This includes analysis, synthesis, enhancement, transformation, classification and interpretation of such signals as well as the design, development, and evaluation of associated signal processing systems. Machine learning and pattern analysis applied to any of the above areas is also welcome.  Specific topics of interest include: auditory modeling and hearing aids; acoustic beamforming and source localization; classification of acoustic scenes; speaker separation; active noise control and echo cancellation; enhancement; de-reverberation; bioacoustics; music signals analysis, synthesis and modification; music information retrieval;  audio for multimedia and joint audio-video processing; spoken and written language modeling, segmentation, tagging, parsing, understanding, and translation; text mining; speech production, perception, and psychoacoustics; speech analysis, synthesis, and perceptual modeling and coding; robust speech recognition; speaker recognition and characterization; deep learning, online learning, and graphical models applied to speech, audio, and language signals; and implementation aspects ranging from system architecture to fast algorithms. #> 45                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Theory, algorithms, and architectures for the formation, capture, processing, communication, analysis, and display of images, video, and multidimensional signals in a wide variety of applications. Topics of interest include: mathematical, statistical, and perceptual image and video modeling and representation; linear and nonlinear filtering, de-blurring, enhancement, restoration, and reconstruction from degraded, low-resolution or tomographic data; lossless and lossy compression and coding; segmentation, alignment, and recognition; image rendering, visualization, and printing; computational imaging, including ultrasound, tomographic and magnetic resonance imaging; and image and video analysis, synthesis, storage, search and retrieval. #> 46                                                                                                                  Theory, algorithms, performance analysis and applications of signal and data analysis, including physical modeling, processing, detection and parameter estimation, learning, mining, retrieval, and information extraction. The term "signal" includes speech, audio, sonar, radar, geophysical, physiological, (bio-) medical, image, video, and multimodal natural and man-made signals, including communication signals and data. Topics of interest include: statistical signal processing, spectral estimation and system identification; filter design, adaptive filtering / stochastic learning; (compressive) sampling, sensing, and transform-domain methods including fast algorithms; signal processing for machine learning and machine learning for signal processing applications; in-network and graph signal processing; convex and nonconvex optimization methods for signal processing applications; radar, sonar, and sensor array beamforming and direction finding; communications signal processing; low power, multi-core and system-on-chip signal processing; sensing, communication, analysis and optimization for cyber-physical systems such as power grids and the Internet of Things. #> 47                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              This section includes theoretical and experimental research covering all facets of automatic control systems. what: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
title: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
text: Allows progammatic searching arXiv pre-print repository.

title: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
code: arxiv_search(   query = NULL,   id_list = NULL,   start = 0,   limit = 10,   sort_by = c("submitted", "updated", "relevance"),   ascending = TRUE,   batchsize = 100,   force = FALSE,   output_format = c("data.frame", "list"),   sep = "|" )

title: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
text: query Search pattern string; vector strings also allowed, case elements combined . id_list arXiv doc IDs, comma-delimited string vector strings start offset start search limit Maximum number records return. sort_by sort results (ignored id_list provided) ascending TRUE, sort ascending order; else descending (ignored id_list provided) batchsize Maximum number records request one time force TRUE, force search request even seems extreme output_format Indicates whether output data frame list. sep String use separate multiple authors, affiliations, DOI links, categories, case output_format="data.frame".

title: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
text: output_format="data.frame", result data frame row manuscript columns various fields. output_format="list", result list parsed XML output search, closer raw output arXiv. data frame format following columns. contents strings; missing values empty strings (""). columns authors, affiliations, link_doi, categories may multiple entries separated sep (default, "|"). result includes attribute "search_info" includes information details search parameters, including time completed. Another attribute "total_results" total number records match query.

title: The main search function for aRxiv — arxiv_search
code: old_delay <- getOption("aRxiv_delay")           options(aRxiv_delay=1) # \donttest{ # search for author Peter Hall with deconvolution in title z <- arxiv_search(query = 'au:"Peter Hall" AND ti:deconvolution', limit=2) attr(z, "total_results") # total no. records matching query #> [1] 4 z$title #> [1] "A ridge-parameter approach to deconvolution" #> [2] "On deconvolution with repeated measurements"  # search for a set of documents by arxiv identifiers z <- arxiv_search(id_list = c("0710.3491v1", "0804.0713v1", "1003.0315v1")) # can also use a comma-separated string z <- arxiv_search(id_list = "0710.3491v1,0804.0713v1,1003.0315v1") # Journal references, if available z$journal_ref #> [1] "Annals of Statistics 2007, Vol. 35, No. 4, 1535-1558" #> [2] "Annals of Statistics 2008, Vol. 36, No. 2, 665-685"   #> [3] ""                                                      # search for a range of dates (in this case, one day) z <- arxiv_search("submittedDate:[199701010000 TO 199701012400]", limit=2) # } options(aRxiv_delay=old_delay)
